Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a High-Performance Computing System for University of Central Arkansas

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project, acquiring a high performance computing and storage infrastructure, aims to accelerate faculty research and enable enhanced research participation opportunities and learning experiences for students in cutting-edge areas. The specific instrument, a blade server system, contains a storage area network subsystem for use by faculty and students in the Department of Computer Science, and by other faculty members and their students' research assistants in Biology, Mathematics, and Geography. Their research projects, in areas that include image analysis, virtual reality, and data mining, require the use of high performance resources and other advanced applications. The project constitutes a major instrumentation enhancement to this mainly undergraduate serving institution. The instrumentation provides or promotes:

-High performance computing and storage infrastructure to support large image databases, virtual reality, and data mining research;
-Access to vast amount of experimental data from outside the campus;
-Multidisciplinary use of common equipment and infrastructure;
-Enhancement of current research efforts; and
-Creation of new synergy among various research groups that may lead to scholarly publications and additional research ideas.

New research ideas and initiatives are expected to emerge leading to additional high quality interdisciplinary research activities that may enhance socioeconomic progress for the state and beyond.

Broader Impacts:
The instrumentation supports an improved learning environment that will contribute to integrate research and education and foster collaborations within the university, and further serve as a bridge to other institutions. The project directly benefits approximately 150 undergraduate students and at least 25 graduate students per year. The research training and education supported by the Blade Server System should contribute to the development of a skilled workforce. Acquisition and utilization of this new instrumentation expands opportunities for a diverse community in an underserved area of the country.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The acquisition of high performance computing (HPC) infrastructure aims to accelerate faculty research and enable enhanced research participation opportunities and learning experiences for students in cutting-edge areas. The HPC system is a blade server system and is designed for use by faculty members and students in the Department of Computer Science and by certain other faculty members, and their student research assistants, in Biology, Chemistry, Mathematics, and Geography. These faculty members are involved in research projects requiring the use of HPC resources for image analysis, virtual reality, data mining, and other advanced applications. All of these research projects involve undergraduate students and some involve graduate students.

The HPC system is currently operational and housed in a secure room on the campus of University of Central Arkansas. We developed a user guide and offered a training session to students and faculty in Spring 2020. We plan to have a training session every semester. The user guide and the training session slides are publicly available on our supercomputer webpage: https://uca.edu/computerscience/supercomputer/. The system is being used in various research projects. It is also being used in various classes such as CSCI 4340: Parallel Programming and CSCI 4370: Data Mining. We plan to use it in other classes such as CSCI 3385: Artificial Intelligence and CSCI 4371: Machine Learning as well.
